Parenting has never been easy, but in the age of social media and internet, it has become more complicated than ever. As parents, we are constantly bombarded with conflicting advice on what to do and what not to do. It can be overwhelming and confusing, especially for first-time parents.
When I became a parent for the first time, I was lost in the sea of parenting advice. I read several books on parenting and childcare, but most of them were too academic or preachy. That is when I stumbled upon a book that changed my approach to parenting- "The Whole-Brain Child" by Daniel J. Siegel and Tina Payne Bryson.
The book is filled with practical tips backed by science. It taught me how to connect with my child on a deeper level and appreciate her tantrums as a way of communicating her emotions. It also helped me understand how to develop my child's executive functioning skills, which are essential for success in life.
Since then, I have read several books on parenting and childcare, and I have curated a list of the best ones for you. These books are based on research and practical experience and will help you become a better parent.
This book is a game-changer for parents who struggle with discipline. The authors promote a parenting style that is both loving and logical. The book teaches parents how to set limits without resorting to threats or punishments.

Channing Tatum, renowned actor, producer, and dancer, has recently added another role to his repertoire: author. His debut children's book, The One and Only Sparkella, is a heartwarming story about a father and his daughter learning to embrace their uniqueness and sparkle on their own terms. But what many may not know is that Sparkella's story has also taught Tatum a thing or two about parenting.
As a father of a young daughter, Tatum has eagerly taken on the joys and challenges of parenthood. However, as many parents can attest, there is no instruction manual or right way to raise a child. With the help of Sparkella, Tatum has found guiding principles that have helped him navigate his journey as a dad.
Sparkella's lessons are not just reserved for her fictional world; they have had a tangible impact on Tatum's parenting style. Here are some of the ways in which Tatum has applied Sparkella's wisdom to his life as a dad:
Sparkella is a shining example of embracing creativity. Whether it's through her love of dressing up, dancing, or storytelling, Sparkella is unapologetic about expressing herself. Tatum has taken this lesson to heart and encourages his daughter to explore and create in her own unique way. He shares that "a lot of times, creativity is shamed out of kids as they grow up. That's not what we want for our daughter."
This has led to some fun and imaginative experiences for Tatum and his daughter, such as building a cardboard castle together or creating silly songs. Tatum believes that fostering creativity not only allows his daughter to have fun but also helps her develop problem-solving skills and boosts her confidence.

As summer approaches, co-parents face a dilemma. On one hand, they want to spend quality time with their children and create lasting memories. On the other hand, they have to navigate schedules, plan activities, and deal with the logistics of co-parenting.
Take the case of Lisa and Tom, who are divorced and have two children, 8-year-old Sarah and 6-year-old Jack. Lisa works full-time as a nurse and has a tight schedule, while Tom runs his own business and has more flexibility. They have agreed to split the summer break in half, with each parent having the children for 6 weeks. Lisa has planned a family trip to the beach for the first week of her custody, but has to work on the other weeks. Tom has signed up the kids for a summer camp and a music workshop during his custody, but has to attend a business conference for a few days.
Lisa and Tom's situation is not unique. According to a survey by the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers, 75% of family law attorneys report an increase in disputes over summer vacation and custody schedules. Another survey by Custody X Change, a software company that helps parents create parenting plans, found that the most common summer custody schedules are alternating weeks, extended weekends, and splitting the summer in half.

Being a parent can be tough, especially when trying to get your child to smile for a photo. One dad from Florida, however, has come up with a hilarious parenting hack that has gone viral on social media.
When Greg Eichhorn's son refused to cooperate for a family photo, Eichhorn decided to get creative. He fashioned a fake set of teeth made from candy corn and popped them into his mouth. The result was an instant burst of laughter from his son, who couldn't help but smile at the sight of his dad's new look.
Eichhorn shared a video of the hilarious moment on TikTok, and it quickly went viral. Parents everywhere have been using Eichhorn's hack to get their own kids to smile for photos, and it has become a trend on social media.
The popularity of Eichhorn's parenting hack is evidenced by the numbers. The video has garnered over 5 million views on TikTok alone, and has been shared on countless parenting blogs and social media sites.
But the real proof of its success can be seen in the countless photos and videos shared by parents who have tried the candy corn teeth trick on their own children. One parent on Twitter shared a video of their son laughing uncontrollably at the sight of his dad's new teeth, with the caption "It really works!"

When Lisa and Alex found out they were going to have a baby, they were ecstatic. They spent hours daydreaming about what their new life would look like with their little one. They talked about all the things they would do as a family, the new experiences they would have, and the love they would share. Every ultrasound, doctor's appointment, and kick they felt was a reminder of the joy that was soon to come.
But after their daughter was born, things weren't quite what they expected. They were exhausted, overwhelmed, and scared. Lisa struggled with breastfeeding and felt like a failure. Alex felt like he didn't know how to help and worried he wasn't doing enough. They both felt like they had lost a part of their identity and didn't know how to find it again. They loved their daughter deeply, but they didn't know how to make sense of this new life they were living.
Fortunately, Lisa and Alex were able to find their way through those early months. They learned how to work together, ask for help, and cherish the small moments. They discovered that parenthood was a journey full of unexpected twists and turns, but that it was also a journey full of love and meaning.

Kids today face a range of stressors from school pressure, peer pressure, relationship problems and family difficulties. Summer fun is in full swing, but so are the digital distractions. With long days and endless free time, it can be tough to keep kids from spending all day in front of a screen. As a parenting pro, I have seen the negative impact of excessive screen time first-hand, and I am here to share my top tips for managing summer screen time in a way that keeps your kids engaged and productive.

She wanted to make sure her kids weren't wasting their summer, but she also didn't want to resort to being a strict enforcer. Together, we came up with a plan that worked for her family.

I knew I needed to take action, so I scheduled a family meeting to discuss our screen time rules. We set a limit of 2 hours per day, and we brainstormed a list of fun activities we could do together as a family. We went on hikes, visited the local pool, and even started a garden! By the end of the summer, my kids were more active and engaged than ever, and I felt like we had really bonded as a family.

About a year ago, my friend gave birth to a beautiful baby girl. As any new mother would, she was extremely careful about what she used on her baby's delicate skin. Confused about which baby powder to choose, she asked her mother, who advised her to use talcum powder, which had been used for generations in their family. My friend followed the advice and used it regularly on her baby, but little did she know about the dangers it posed.
Talcum powder is made from talc, a mineral that is found in rocks. It is widely used because of its ability to absorb moisture and reduce friction, making it effective as a deodorant and a cosmetic product. Unfortunately, it also contains asbestos, a carcinogen that has been linked to lung cancer and other serious health problems. Asbestos is often found in natural talc, which is why regular use of talcum powder can be dangerous, especially for infants.
In 2018, Johnson & Johnson was ordered to pay $4.7 billion in damages to a group of 22 women who claimed that the company's talcum powder caused their ovarian cancer.
According to the American Cancer Society, there is no safe or acceptable level of asbestos exposure. While many talcum powder products are now asbestos-free, the risk of contamination cannot be ruled out entirely, as talc is frequently mined alongside asbestos. Moreover, even talcum powder that is free of asbestos can still be harmful to babies, as they can accidentally inhale it, leading to respiratory problems such as pneumonia.

It was a typical lazy Saturday afternoon in the Roloff household, with little Bode, the 3-year-old bundle of energy, running around the house. As he ran past the living room carrying his favorite toy car, he stumbled upon a trip hazard, lost his footing, and fell face forward onto the sharp edges of the coffee table. Audrey could hear the bloodcurdling screams from the kitchen and rushed to find her little one writhing in pain with a bloody gash to the forehead.
This is a scene familiar to many parents. Children have an innate curiosity and boundless energy. It is what makes them so adorable, but it also poses a significant risk to their safety. As parents, it is our responsibility to keep our children safe from harm, and that starts with childproofing our homes. According to the National Safety Council, home accidents are one of the leading causes of death and injury in children under age 5.
To make your home safe for children, you need to get rid of the clutter. It is easy to overlook potential risks when there is too much stuff in the way. Start by decluttering your home one room at a time and donate, sell, or trash anything that is broken or outdated. Keep the floors clear of toys, clothing, and other items that could cause your child to trip and fall.
Children are mischievous and love to climb on furniture. They can easily tip over chairs, tables, and bookcases, which can cause serious injuries. Anchor your furniture to the wall to prevent tipping. Use furniture straps or L-brackets to secure tall furniture such as bookcases, dressers, and TV stands. Cover the sharp edges of furniture with corner protectors to prevent cuts and bruises.
Safety gates are a crucial tool for childproofing your home. They prevent your child from accessing areas of the home that are not safe, such as stairs or rooms with potential hazards. There are different types of safety gates available that you can use depending on the layout of your home and your child's age. Pressure-mounted gates are easy to install and are ideal for blocking off areas temporarily. Hardware-mounted gates are more secure and are ideal for use in areas that will be blocked off for a longer period.
